Founding Location
Your first decision is to pick a location for your startup. Some areas are more expensive than others, and your choice will impact future access to capital, talent, and internet connectivity.
Tech Hub – expensive but with world class talent and tons of investors
This is the place to be, and even if that co-working space only gives you a desk in the corner for 3x the cost of a full office somewhere else, you'll be seen as a *real* startup now.

Recruiting
What are you prioritizing in your recruiting?
The best candidates, regardless of their cost or if they need to work remotely
A rockstar employee is worth 10x just a “good” employee. You should spare no expense in hiring as many rock stars as possible.
Recruiting
What are you prioritizing in your recruiting?

Recruiting
What are you prioritizing in your recruiting?
We're going to hire smart but inexperienced people and train them
People with too much experience can drag you down. They're still stuck in the past. You need smart kids with passion and excitement to build something truly revolutionary.
Recruiting
What are you prioritizing in your recruiting?
we'll outsource as much of the work as possible to an inexpensive team overseas

Getting a minimum viable product out as quickly as possible is the key to your first mover advantage – and getting an experienced outsourced team to build it for you is how you'll get there. You can iterate later.

Series A
You are starting to run low on cash – it’s time to raise another round. You've tapped your investor network and here are the options available to you:
Layoff some staff and cut other expenses to get to break even

The layoffs are painful and company morale never fully recovers. Meanwhile, your competitors are outpacing you in creating new features and growing their userbase. After a year of grinding away, the writing is on the wall and you wind down the company. Time to look for a real job… or start another company.
Series A
You are starting to run low on cash – it’s time to raise another round. You've tapped your investor network and here are the options available to you:
Self-fund with money from the trust fund / raise for your family’s investment office

It’s good to be able to go back to the well and dip into the family vault, but it’s surprising that investors and star employees don't seem to take you as seriously. The company slowly morphs into more of a vanity business for the founder, rather than a true high growth startup.
wealthyFounder:true

You are starting to run low on cash – it’s time to raise another round. You've tapped your investor network and here are the options available to you:
Raise a modest amount from local angels who don't have a lot of additional value to offer

Series A
You are starting to run low on cash – it’s time to raise another round. You've tapped your investor network and here are the options available to you:
Raise strategic capital from a big business that is interested in seeing you succeed

Series A

Raise a huge round from a well known VC in exchange for 25% of the company
Welcome to the big leagues. You've now got rocket fuel and let’s make your growth chart head towards the moon.

Acquisition: you can sell to Google for $1-2M per engineer
Acquihired… it would have been nice to have built the next trillion dollar business, but here’s a chance to cash in right now and beef up the resume for your next shot.

Round 2

Congratulations! You've closed your new round, moved to a bigger office, and you're starting to hire your next round of employees.

You've got two years of runway, based on your current projections, and your investors fully expect you to spend that in pursuit of aggressive growth.

Meanwhile, having a bigger company means bigger problems to contend with. In fact, your inbox is growing out of control.

Patent Troll

You receive a threat letter from a company that appears to be nothing more than a post-office box in Texas and a lawyer, saying you violate its patent on “e-commerce” without any other details. The letter says that you must settle immediately or the price of settlement will rise.
Pay up, get the troll to go away, it costs less than fighting it anyway
This is annoying, but you really don't have the time to fight a drawn out battle. Just pay up and keep going.
paidTroll:true
Patent Troll

You receive a threat letter from a company that appears to be nothing more than a post-office box in Texas and a lawyer, saying you violate its patent on “e-commerce” without any other details. The letter says that you must settle immediately or the price of settlement will rise.
Ask lawyer to begin negotiations
That settlement offer is ridiculous, but let’s get your lawyer to negotiate the troll down. It’ll be cheaper for them not to have to go to court as well.
paidTroll:true
Patent Troll

You receive a threat letter from a company that appears to be nothing more than a post-office box in Texas and a lawyer, saying you violate its patent on “e-commerce” without any other details. The letter says that you must settle immediately or the price of settlement will rise.
Ignore the troll; “You don't violate that patent.”
What nonsense. Your technology has nothing to do with that patent. That threat can't be real, and if they go to court I'm sure you'll get it dismissed easily.
ignoreTroll:true
Patent Troll

You receive a threat letter from a company that appears to be nothing more than a post-office box in Texas and a lawyer, saying you violate its patent on “e-commerce” without any other details. The letter says that you must settle immediately or the price of settlement will rise.
Tell the troll you’ll never settle, and initiate IPR process against the patent in question

Patent trolls are bad for innovation, and if you don't take a stand, they'll keep doing this to you and others. It’s costly upfront (not to mention time consuming) to invalidate this patent, but it will plant a flag as warning to other potential trolls.
focus:-1,fightTroll:true
NSL

The FBI shows up on your doorstep with an official looking “National Security Letter” demanding you hand over information on three of your users. The letter includes a gag order saying you cannot reveal the existence of the letter or the demand for data.
Hand over the data

The FBI are the good guys, right? If they ask for data, surely they must need it. Of course, when it’s eventually revealed that you were so quick to hand over user data, your users no longer trust you and start migrating to alternatives.
NSL

The FBI shows up on your doorstep with an official looking “National Security Letter” demanding you hand over information on three of your users. The letter includes a gag order saying you cannot reveal the existence of the letter or the demand for data.
Refuse to hand over data and ask lawyer to fight the request

Isn't the 4th Amendment supposed to mean something? Time to hire a lawyer to pushback on this encroachment. It’s super expensive, but if you don't do it and it comes out later, no one will ever trust you again.
fightFBI:true
NSL

The FBI shows up on your doorstep with an official looking “National Security Letter” demanding you hand over information on three of your users. The letter includes a gag order saying you cannot reveal the existence of the letter or the demand for data.
Immediately tell the public that you won't share with the FBI

“Gag order? You don't believe in gag orders. Put out a press release calling out the FBI immediately!” The public rallies behind you, but the DOJ also files a lawsuit, and court after court buys their argument that you just put national security interests at risk. Somewhere in the midst of appeals, you run out of money, even if you are a folk hero among the crowds on social media.
NSL

The FBI shows up on your doorstep with an official looking “National Security Letter” demanding you hand over information on three of your users. The letter includes a gag order saying you cannot reveal the existence of the letter or the demand for data.
Hand over the data and work out a streamlined process for future FBI requests.
The FBI has legitimate reasons for this, and if these kinds of requests are going to happen frequently, you should work out a process so that it doesn't take up as much resources each time.

Local Laws

The state government in your home state passes a very strict new privacy law, requiring significant compliance costs, including requiring a pop up notification for every user that you fear will annoy users.
Move headquarters to a different state; ban users from this state from accessing your service via geoblocking; this state is too unfriendly to innovation

You need to stand up to states being too aggressive with bad regulations stifling entrepreneurs. It’s expensive and distracting to move your entire company, but it’ll be more expensive to stay! Sure, the users in your old state are angry that they can't reach the site, but maybe they'll make their voices heard at the ballot box…

Defamation

A local TV newscaster sends you a cease-and-desist/takedown letter, claiming that one of your users has been posting a series of defamatory accusations about alleged events that took place at a private party a decade ago.  If true, the events would call into question the newscaster’s judgment.
Take it down and suspend the user; you don't want any defamation here, and there’s no way to determine what’s real and what’s not.

Other users immediately talk about how you took down the post and suspended the user, and that story goes viral. High profile users quit the service in protest and a boycott campaign is waged against you demanding that you reverse the ban.
Defamation

A local TV newscaster sends you a cease-and-desist/takedown letter, claiming that one of your users has been posting a series of defamatory accusations about alleged events that took place at a private party a decade ago.  If true, the events would call into question the newscaster’s judgment.
Temporarily disable the content, and alert the user that the content will be permanently disabled unless he files reasonable proof of the claims.

News of the temporary suspension goes viral, as you are accused of “censoring the truth” to help the newscaster. No one seems to care that the disabling was temporary. Users claim they'll be switching to your competitor.
Defamation

A local TV newscaster sends you a cease-and-desist/takedown letter, claiming that one of your users has been posting a series of defamatory accusations about alleged events that took place at a private party a decade ago.  If true, the events would call into question the newscaster’s judgment.
Pass the takedown on to the original poster, asking for a response for you to weigh against the request.

User posts angry screed about how he’s being censored, leading to outrage (even though the original is still up). People start spreading the original story far and wide before any decision is made. Newscaster is even angrier at how you handled this and is threatening legal action. Who has time to adjudicate squabbles like this?!?

Disinformation

And the experts don't always even agree with each other, so you need to hire more experts to check on the other experts.

Disinformation

A viral post on the site presents the results of a scientific study in a manner that some users claim is misleading and out of context. Flag the content as “potentially misleading” with links to verified, trustworthy sources.

Backdoor

FBI very strongly encourages you to revamp your planned privacy/encryption features to include a “golden key” for “lawful access,” that they insist will only be used in extreme cases where a court has determined the FBI has shown probable cause of a crime and requires access to the information.
Tell the FBI this is not possible. Encryption is not encryption with a backdoor

Standing up for the rights of your users sure feels like the right move, but being paraded before Congress, and having law enforcement officials claiming that you're aiding and abetting terrorists is not exactly great for your image.
Backdoor

FBI very strongly encourages you to revamp your planned privacy/encryption features to include a “golden key” for “lawful access,” that they insist will only be used in extreme cases where a court has determined the FBI has shown probable cause of a crime and requires access to the information.
Invest resources in seeking a secure key for lawful access

Surely you can figure out a way to build a key that only law enforcement can use, while still keeping your user’s info safe. But hiring cryptography experts is costly, and they keep telling you it can't be done and quitting. And your users are complaining that you're not taking their privacy concerns seriously as they seek out more secure options.

FBI very strongly encourages you to revamp your planned privacy/encryption features to include a “golden key” for “lawful access,” that they insist will only be used in extreme cases where a court has determined the FBI has shown probable cause of a crime and requires access to the information.

Net Neutrality

MegaTelCo reaches out to let you know that it is negotiating with your largest competitor to zero rate its service -- meaning that users using your competitor’s service won't use up any of their limited bandwidth when using that service. MegaTelCo offers you either an exclusive deal as their “preferred” partner (which will mean Competitor X won't be able to get such a deal) or a less expensive zero rating deal.
Take the exclusive deal; not costing users bandwidth will be a huge boost to your userbase, and it harms Competitor X’s market position.
The deal is really costly, but it’s worth it because users are flocking to your service thanks to the partnership!

EU Regulations

EU passes new Online Personal Data Protection Regulation. It requires much greater transparency and end-user controls over data collected about users for nearly any website, while also requiring significant data retention rules to aid in law enforcement requests.
Apply the user control policies universally as it’s too difficult to regionalize; establish data localization/retention effort
The EU rules are now the global rules. You need to spend to make this all work and to build out compliance systems, but the rules are the rules.

Data Breach

A “Security researcher” contacts you to alert you that he has discovered a large chunk of your user logs on an unsecured cloud instance. Claims this is the second time he has reached out to alert you and plans to go public tomorrow if you haven't paid a security bounty.
Ignore; you don't negotiate with terrorists and you're sure your data is secure.
Everywhere you look since your latest round of funding people are coming up with reasons why you need to pay them! Enough is enough…

Data Breach

A “Security researcher” contacts you to alert you that he has discovered a large chunk of your user logs on an unsecured cloud instance. Claims this is the second time he has reached out to alert you and plans to go public tomorrow if you haven't paid a security bounty.
Pay bounty; lockdown your systems

This is annoying, but that white hat hacker did find a real vulnerability. Better that it was one of the good guys than the opposite. Pay him, thank him, fix the problem and let’s hope you're good going forward.
Data Breach

Pay bounty, lockdown systems, alert your users of the potential breach; offer credit monitoring services to all affected users.

It’s bad that you missed such a big vulnerability, but now you need to make things right. Pay the researcher, fix the hole, and alert your readers to what happened. Some are frustrated that your security was so bad, but at least you're on the track to making things right…
Healthcare Headaches

New, thorough, peer-reviewed, WHO-endorsed study demonstrates that information previously thought to be misleading/misinformation actually is accurate, surprising many. People who spread information making similar claims before and who were banned demand apologies/return of accounts.
Stand by original decision. Your policy is to enforce *current* scientific consensus, not retroactive
Users are mad because to them it was “obvious all along” that the original scientific consensus was wrong. They're saying that you're beholden to Big Science.

India Localization

India implements new data localization rules that require any data collected regarding Indian citizens must be kept on servers in India and that any company with more than 1 million users in India must have a local presence, including an office and employees in India to handle any legal complaints/data demands from the government.
Set up local Indian subsidiary and data operations to comply
The rules are the rules and the market is too important. It’s crazy costly to set up a local subsidiary, but let’s make it happen.

India Localization

India implements new data localization rules that require any data collected regarding Indian citizens must be kept on servers in India and that any company with more than 1 million users in India must have a local presence, including an office and employees in India to handle any legal complaints/data demands from the government.
Proactively turn off service in India; geoblock Indian users

Brazilian Issues
Brazil passes new law which would require global takedowns of content deemed illegal by courts. Failure to comply will result in service being blocked entirely from Brazil.
Comply with such requests; it’s gone through due process, and a global takedown is the only way to truly takedown the judicially recognized illegal content.
We’re taking down the content as demanded, but it’s sure making a bunch of your users angry about how we’re a pawn of the state.
Brazilian Issues
Brazil passes new law which would require global takedowns of content deemed illegal by courts. Failure to comply will result in service being blocked entirely from Brazil.
Block access to such content in Brazil, but keep it up elsewhere.
